clarity_scoring_criteria.0-2_points: Loss of perception or complete inaccuracy. The model has no perception of the changes in audio quality at all. Its clarity judgment results have no correlation with the actual audio quality. Even worse, it often judges low-quality audio as clear or high-quality audio as unclear. The output may contain irrelevant or incorrect descriptions.
clarity_scoring_criteria.3-4_points: Weak perception and often inaccurate. The model has a very weak perception of audio quality and can occasionally make relatively correct judgments in extreme situations (such as extremely low or extremely high quality), but in most cases, the judgments are inaccurate or unstable. Lack of the ability to distinguish intermediate tones.
clarity_scoring_criteria.5-6_points: Possess basic perception ability. The model can make a basic distinction of audio quality and usually correctly determine that high-quality audio is "clear" and very low-quality audio is "unclear". However, the ability to distinguish the intermediate sound quality is limited, and it is prone to errors or giving vague judgments. The judgment result may not be stable enough or lack details.
clarity_scoring_criteria.7-8_points: Good perception and basically accurate judgment. The model can make accurate clarity judgments for most common sound quality levels. It can well reflect the changing trend of sound quality (the higher the quality, the clearer the judgment). It can also make reasonable judgments on some medium or slightly challenging sound qualities, but occasionally may make mistakes in judging subtle differences.
clarity_scoring_criteria.9-10_points: The perception is very strong and highly accurate. The model can continuously and accurately judge the clarity of audio and make accurate and consistent evaluations of various sound quality levels (including subtle differences). The judgment result is highly consistent with the actual audio quality, and even the traces brought by audio coding or processing can be reflected through the judgment (such as "It sounds a bit compressed").
